body_html:
@ribx I tried python setup.py --help-commands under the tmp directory, and got this:

(...)
Extra commands:
  saveopts          save supplied options to setup.cfg or other config file
  develop           install package in 'development mode'
  bdist_mpkg        create a Mac OS X mpkg distribution for Installer.app
  upload_docs       Upload documentation to PyPI
  test              run unit tests after in-place build
  setopt            set an option in setup.cfg or another config file
  install_egg_info  Install an .egg-info directory for the package
  rotate            delete older distributions, keeping N newest files
  egg_info          create a distribution's .egg-info directory
  py2app            create a Mac OS X application or plugin from Python scripts
  alias             define a shortcut to invoke one or more commands
  easy_install      Find/get/install Python packages
  bdist_egg         create an "egg" distribution

usage: setup.py [global_opts] cmd1 [cmd1_opts] [cmd2 [cmd2_opts] ...]
   or: setup.py --help [cmd1 cmd2 ...]
   or: setup.py --help-commands
   or: setup.py cmd --help

I didn't found bdist_wheel.

My tensorflow is installed under /Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.6/lib/python3.6/site-packages/tensorflow
This means

python3 --version
Python 3.6.2rc1

is used for tensorflow, right? I tried install wheel with both pip install wheel and pip3 install wheel, but it shows wheel is already there.

What should I do now...

body:
@ribx I tried `python setup.py --help-commands` under the tmp directory, and got this:
```
(...)
Extra commands:
  saveopts          save supplied options to setup.cfg or other config file
  develop           install package in 'development mode'
  bdist_mpkg        create a Mac OS X mpkg distribution for Installer.app
  upload_docs       Upload documentation to PyPI
  test              run unit tests after in-place build
  setopt            set an option in setup.cfg or another config file
  install_egg_info  Install an .egg-info directory for the package
  rotate            delete older distributions, keeping N newest files
  egg_info          create a distribution's .egg-info directory
  py2app            create a Mac OS X application or plugin from Python scripts
  alias             define a shortcut to invoke one or more commands
  easy_install      Find/get/install Python packages
  bdist_egg         create an "egg" distribution

usage: setup.py [global_opts] cmd1 [cmd1_opts] [cmd2 [cmd2_opts] ...]
   or: setup.py --help [cmd1 cmd2 ...]
   or: setup.py --help-commands
   or: setup.py cmd --help
```
I didn't found `bdist_wheel`.

My tensorflow is installed under `/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.6/lib/python3.6/site-packages/tensorflow`
This means  
```
python3 --version
Python 3.6.2rc1
```
is used for tensorflow, right? I tried install wheel with both `pip install wheel` and `pip3 install wheel`, but it shows wheel is already there.

What should I do now...
